title: How to Burn Weeds in Rocks

parts.name: Safeguarding the Work Area and Yourself

steps.headline: Kill weeds when they’re young and tender.
steps.description: Weeds that have recently emerged from the rocks are easier to kill than those that have had time to grow taller and thicker. Bigger weeds with tougher stalks may take more flame treatments to kill, and their wilted remains will take longer to disappear.In many cases, it’s best to do your first flame treatment when the first weeds pop up in the spring. Additional treatments may be required in any case, but you’ll likely cut back on the total number of treatments needed.

steps.headline: Wait for a wind-free day not long after it has rained.
steps.description: Do not use a landscaping torch if there are winds above a very gentle 3–5 mi (4.8–8.0 km) per hour breeze. Otherwise, leaves or other flammable debris could blow past your torch and ignite. Whenever possible, also time your treatment so it occurs within 24 hours after a rain shower.Rainy weather makes surrounding debris less flammable, and wet rocks, soil, and weeds also conduct heat from the torch flame much more efficiently. Type "wind speed forecast today" and your location into your preferred search engine to get up-to-date info.

steps.headline: Remove leaves and all flammable debris from the area.
steps.description: Use (preferably) a leaf blower or a broom to clear away all the leaves, fallen twigs, and other potential fire hazards from the rocks you’ll be torching. Follow up by picking up any remaining flammable debris in the rocks by hand.Wet leaves are less likely to ignite immediately, but they can still catch fire when exposed to a 2,000 °F (1,090 °C) torch flame!

steps.headline: Put on long clothing, heavy boots, and thick gloves.
steps.description: A torch flame can severely burn your skin in a fraction of a second, so protective gear is a must. Wear thick, fire-resistant work gloves and heavy, insulated work boots. Put on heavy-duty work pants (like thick jeans) and a long-sleeve work shirt as well.Consider taking off metal jewelry and accessories as well, as these can heat up extremely rapidly and cause serious burns. When the proper precautions are taken, “flaming” weeds is nearly always a safe process. However, if you still have concerns, opt for a different weed-killing technique.

steps.headline: Choose a “flamer” that’s easy to use and suits your needs.
steps.description: Buy a landscaping torch that's made specifically for killing weeds from a reputable brick-and-mortar or web-based home improvement retailer. Consider factors such as the following when choosing a “flamer”:The wand. The torch should have a 3–4 ft (0.91–1.22 m) metal wand that lets you target the flame right along the ground without having to bend down. Ignition and shut-off. A torch with a push-button ignition is easier and safer to handle than one that requires the use of a sparking tool. Additionally, look for a torch with an easy-to-reach propane shut-off valve.

steps.headline: Select a propane tank to use with your chosen torch.
steps.description: These are typically sold separately and connect by screwing the torch’s tube securely onto the tank’s valve. A small, 16  fl oz (470 ml) tank is easier to carry and may provide about 1 hour of flame time. A large, 5 US gal (19 L) tank provides at least 6 hours of flame time but requires either backpack-style straps to carry it or a longer supply tube.Both small and large propane tanks are widely available at a range of retailers. Follow the connection instructions on the tank carefully when attaching the propane to your torch.

steps.headline: Water the area thoroughly with a garden hose.
steps.description: Unless the rocks and surrounding ground are completely saturated from recent rain, give everything a good soaking before using your torch. Doing so cuts back on the risk of fire while also increasing the effectiveness of your “flamer.”When the rocks and the top layer of soil beneath them are wet, they transfer heat more quickly and more completely to the stems and roots of the weeds. This will help you kill weeds you can’t even see yet! Keep the garden hose nearby and ready to go while you use the landscaping torch. It’s also a good idea to have a fire extinguisher in the general vicinity.

steps.headline: Engage the push-button ignition to light most modern "flamers."
steps.description: Modern, high-quality landscaping torches usually ignite by simply turning a couple of levers and pushing a button. Turn on the propane valves on the tank and supply tube, then press the ignition button near the wand’s handle. Hold the bottom of the wand directly over the rocks and away from any flammable material when you ignite it.Follow the product guide for specific instructions for your model.

steps.headline: Use a sparking tool to light a “flamer” without a push-button ignition.
steps.description: Turn on the propane valves and hold the bottom tip of the wand upright but away from your face and body. Hold the sparking tool in your gloved hand about 1 in (2.5 cm) from the wand tip and click it until the propane ignites. If you don’t get ignition within 10-15 seconds, turn off the propane and wait at least 2 minutes before trying again.You can find a sparking tool at any home improvement store. It's possible, but not recommended for safety reasons, to use a long match to light the torch.

steps.headline: Kill unseen weeds by walking slowly and waving the wand over the rocks.
steps.description: Instead of simply targeting the individual weeds you can see, wave the torch over the entire area that you want to keep weed-free. Walk at a slow, 1–2 mi (1.6–3.2 km) per hour pace and wave the flame back and forth over the rocks. Keep the tip of the torch about 2–3 in (5.1–7.6 cm) from the tops of the rocks, and be sure to keep the flame at least 1 ft (30 cm) away from your boots and any flammable materials.The 2,000 °F (1,090 °C) heat of the torch will kill weeds that haven’t yet emerged from the rocks, and may even kill ones that have just begun to germinate.

steps.headline: Hold the torch over individual weeds for a fraction of a second.
steps.description: When you do come across a visible weed while walking with the torch, hold the flame over it for a very brief pause—a quarter of a second is more than adequate. The heat of the flame will almost instantaneously destroy the vital internal structures of the weed.You don’t need to incinerate the weeds. A quick dose of extreme heat will do the job much more quickly and safely.

steps.headline: Aim to smell cooking greens, not burnt grass.
steps.description: Your sense of smell is often the best way to tell if you’re doing the job right. If it smells like you’re sautéing kale or spinach on the stovetop, you’re right on track! If, however, it smells like you left the kale or spinach on the stovetop too long and burned it to a crisp, wave the “flamer” more quickly over the rocks.Remember, your goal isn’t to actually “burn” the weeds—do not try to set them on fire. Instead, watch for them to immediately wilt and perhaps very slightly brown.

steps.headline: Turn off the torch and stay clear of its hot tip.
steps.description: When you’re finished “flaming,” shut off the propane valves to kill the flame. Keep in mind, however, that the tip of the wand may stay hot to the touch for 5-10 minutes after you’re done. For safety, dunk it in a bucket of water or spray it with the hose. If this isn’t possible, lay it on the rocks to cool, well away from any flammable material.Don’t leave the hot torch wand unattended while it cools.

steps.headline: Repeat the process up to 4 times at 2-to-3-week intervals.
steps.description: The visible weeds you torch will wilt completely within a few hours, and it’s fine to just let them decompose in place. However, there will almost certainly be some seedlings that survive your initial attack, so plan to give the rocks another round with the “flamer” in about 2-3 weeks. Follow the same procedure as before.Weeds are amazingly resilient plants, so don’t be shocked if you still spot some after the second treatment. It may take up to 4 treatments, spread out over 2-3 months total, to get rid of all the weeds for the season.
